ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION

SAFETY IN USE OF CRANES AT CONSTRUCTION SITES

     The following Question stood in the name of Mdm Halimah Yacob -

 

     1.  To ask the Minister for Manpower whether his Ministry will consider enhancing safety in the use of cranes at construction sites, including reviewing the Factories (Operations of Cranes) Regulations in view of the massive construction works going on and the recent fatal accident at NUS when a crane toppled over and killed three workers.

 

Column: 2325

     Ms Jessica Tan Soon Neo (East Coast): Question No. 1, Sir.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Manpower (Mr Hawazi Daipi) (for the Minister for Manpower):   Sir, there are already stringent requirements in place to minimise the risks involved in the use of cranes. Under the WSH (General Provisions) Regulations, all cranes, especially their foundation supports, must be regularly tested and certified by Professional Engineers before they can be erected and used. These requirements are in line with international best practices. The Factories (Operation of Crane) Regulations further stipulate that only crane contractors approved by MOM can erect, install, dismantle or repair cranes. Crane operators must also be authorised by MOM. In addition, MOM requires contractors to appoint dedicated personnel, such as lifting supervisors, riggers and signalmen, to supervise all lifting works involving cranes. There are also approved codes of practice outlining the safe use of various types of cranes.

 

     Since the collapse of the tower crane at NUS, MOM has stepped up efforts to remind the construction industry about the safe use of cranes, especially the need to inspect the cranes before use and the measures for safe operation.  Inspections of tower cranes have also been stepped up. To complement the Ministry's efforts, the Workplace Safety and Health Advisory Committee has shared the findings from other crane accidents with over 200 crane owners and other industry stakeholders. It is also developing a checklist to help construction industry stakeholders better address safety issues with crane suppliers and maintenance companies.

 

     Investigations into the NUS accident are still on-going. MOM will take on board any relevant findings and review the regulations if there is a need.

          The Chairman:  Head W – Ministry of Transport.  Amendment No. (1).

 

Contestability for the Bus and Rail Sectors

 

     Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng (West Coast): Sir, I beg to move,

 

     That the total sum to be allocated for Head W of the Estimates be reduced by $100.

 

      Sir, Singapore distinguishes itself from other nations in many ways.  We have been successful in attracting and retaining foreign direct investments and talents partly because we have an efficient transport infrastructure.  Our air and sea ports consistently rank among the best and are held as benchmarks by others.  Yet, we plan ahead and constantly improve our air and sea infrastructure.  Geographically, Bangkok is closer to the world's major cities by air and Thailand has more tourist traffic. As seaports,

Column: 2327

Tanjong Pelapas and Batam are just short detours from Singapore for long-ocean voyages.  As a small economy without a sizeable origin and destination traffic, Singapore's success as a transport hub does not come naturally. We need always to be a 'few steps ahead' to capture the transit passengers and the transshipment cargoes.  So, even as we opened Changi Terminal 3, T4 is already on the cards.  We have also been adding berths at Pasir Panjang Terminals, always a 'few steps ahead'.

 

     Moving on to land transport, we do have a reasonably good land transport infrastructure today but we need to plan ahead as our land transport infrastructure is clearly under strain and our challenges are plenty. 

 

     The Government has projected that the population in Singapore would increase from 4.5 million today to 5.5 million to 6.5 million in the near future.  Add to that, Singapore is competing to be a major MICE destination. So tourist arrival is expected to increase from 10.2 million last year to 15 million by 2012, a 50% increase, and the target is also to get these tourists to stay longer in Singapore.  This is achievable, given our two integrated resorts, F1, Youth Olympics, Arts and Sports Hub ambitions, and so forth.  MOT's recent land transport review is therefore very timely but the question is whether or not our Land Transport Masterplan is up to the task.  Are these measures effective, and do they go far enough? 

 

     The Masterplan has three main thrusts: firstly, to make public transport the choice mode; secondly, to manage road usage; and thirdly, to meet the diverse needs of the public. 

 

     Sir, let me focus on the first thrust, which is to make public transport the choice mode.  I believe this is an imperative for Singapore.  We are but 700 sq km

Column: 2328

and already 12% of our island is used for roads.  There are three main ways to move around in Singapore - by rail, by bus or by private cars and taxis.  Some of my parliamentary colleagues will say that bicycles or walking is also a way.  But, really, these are not mass transport movers.  Cars and taxis are the least efficient ways to move large number of commuters.  It takes three or four passengers.  Buses are better, but they compete for road space with other motorists. 

 

    The vehicle growth rate, in terms of new COEs to be issued, will be reduced from 3% to1.5% per year.  Contrast that with the forecasted supply in terms of road lane-kilometre of 0.5% per year.  So, if  you do the mathematics, it is clear that we cannot afford to have more vehicles on the road and we must increase the share of commuters on public transport.  Indeed, we should encourage motorists to say "my other car is a bus".  But, I think, better still, if they would say "my other car is a train".

 

     Rail – Sir, I believe is the best mass people mover.  Compared to bus, it is faster, it is safer, it is more comfortable, it is more time-definite, it is more reliable, and it is more environmentally-friendly.

 

     Currently, our buses carry twice as many passengers or passenger trips compared to our rail system. For every passenger trip made on the rail, we have two passenger trips on the bus.  In New York, it is the reverse - twice as many passenger trips are made on the New York subway compared to buses.  In Tokyo, the ratio of rail passenger trips to bus passenger trips is about 15 rail trips to one bus trip. 

 

     The Masterplan calls for rail capacity to triple by 2020.  This is good news but the ratio of rail-bus trips would only improve from 0.5 to 1.5, still below the ratio for New York and well below the ratio for Tokyo.  Moreover, the bulk of the

Column: 2329

capacity increase will occur only in the latter part of the 2008-2020 period.  The DTL Stage 2 will be ready only in seven years' time, and that is in 2015; DTL Stage 3 in 2016.  The Thomson Line or TSL in 2018, and the Eastern Region Line or ERL only in 2020.

 

     The $40 billion MRT investment announced recently is commendable and certainly in the right direction, but is it enough?  Yes, initial investments in rail infrastructure are high, but so are the returns.  It is heartening to note that MOT will now evaluate rail investments on a network basis and not on a line-by-line basis, as they did in the past.  The externalities that come with rail investments are massive – better connectivity (which improves exponentially every time you add a node to the rail infrastructure), enhancement in land and property prices around MRT stations, relieve road congestion, boost to the construction sector, job creation, and so forth.

 

     Sir, I would urge the Ministry to re-examine the size and the pace of rail investments, and to advise if the scope of the recent land transport review includes the study on the optimum mix between rail and bus for Singapore.  And if so, what is this optimum mix?

 

     Next, contestability.  I fully agree that "competition for the market" every few years is the right model for Singapore.  I understand that MOT is studying how to go about it.  I would urge MOT to open the tender to all experienced operators, both local and foreign, and also to adopt a two-envelope system.  With the two-envelope bidding system, the bidder will submit a price proposal separately from the technical proposal.  Technical proposal is always opened and assessed first before the price envelope is opened.  If the first envelope does not meet the requirements, there is no point going on to consider the

Column: 2330

second envelope as the service standards will not be met.  Such a system ensures that the price proposal will not influence the assessment of the technical proposal.

 

     In structuring the bids, we could adopt either a 'gross cost method' or a 'net cost method'.  Under the 'gross cost method', the PTO will not assume any transport fare risks.  It bids only on the basis of meeting prescribed standards and its costs of operating the service.  Under this system, the Government agencies will set fares and collect all transport fares to pay for capital investments and to the successful PTOs for operating costs.  Sir, this system is better because it forces the PTOs to bid aggressively.  And it has been shown that some 20% to 30% cost savings can be achieved if fare risks are removed from the PTOs. The converse method of 'net cost method' requiring the PTOs to assume fare risks would result, I believe, in higher operating cost.

 

Incentives for Motorists to Switch to Public Transport

 

     Sir, other than supply management which we discussed earlier, demand management is equally important.  Both measures are necessary and each measure on its own is not sufficient.  Road usage is one such form of demand management.  ERP rates are likely to rise, given that we will soon adopt the 85th percentile speed benchmark in lieu of the average speed benchmark.  For expressways, the optimal speed is set at 45 kilometres per hour, and for arterial roads 20 kilometres per hour.  If we are successful, some motorists may wish to switch to public transport during peak hours but still retain their cars for off-peak use.  LTA introduced the Off-Peak Car (or OPC) Scheme in 1994.  For newly registered cars, a combined reduction of $17,000 in COE and ARF has been offered.  In addition, there is a reduction in annual road tax of $800, subject to a minimum of $50.  For conversion of normal cars to

Column: 2331

OPC Scheme, a proportionate reduction in COE and ARF is currently disallowed.  Instead, a back-end additional PARF is granted when the car is de-registered.

 

 

          The Chairman: Please finish your speech, Mr Foo.

 

 

     Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister if he could consider enhancing the benefits for OPC Scheme so that more motorists will switch to the OPC Scheme.

 

Land Transport System

 

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): I welcome the Minister's announcement on the new philosophy to put the commuters at the centre of our land transport system.  His announcement reflects an attitude which was not embraced in the past by the Government.  The centralised planning of bus routes is a sign that the Government is now willing to undertake direct responsibility of public transport efficiency and to answer directly to the public on service standards. 

 

     In the quest for a people-centred transport system, I am concerned about the price that commuters and taxpayers have to pay for the system to be centred on them.  Will the Minister tell us if the new initiatives, which include making our hub-and-spoke system seamless as well as building more air-conditioned bus interchanges, result in a higher cost of transport for Singaporeans? 

 

     There are also plans to enhance contestability of bus services by introducing competition for the market where operators compete periodically for the right to provide a package of bus services designed by LTA.  Will such plans result in real market competition with different operators bidding down prices that will benefit consumers?  My concern is whether the requirement of the level of capital and track record will be so onerous

Column: 2332

as to preclude smaller players who could give the incumbent players serious competition. 

 

     The Ministry's earlier approach in introducing competition has resulted in the present duopoly of bus services between SMRT-TIBS and SBS-Transit. Will the same fate fall on these new initiatives?  I would like the Minister to clarify the principle upon which the contestability of bus services would be implemented.  How would the Minister facilitate innovation and entrepreneurship for smaller players to compete effectively against Temasek-linked incumbents?

 

     Lastly, the Minister, in answering a question filed by Ms Sylvia Lim, the Party Chairman, said that the LTA's foreign consultant report would be released as part of the report on the Land Transport Review.  I would like to know if the said report has been released to the public.

 

 

          The Chairman:  Mr Siew Kum Hong is not here.  Mr Lim Biow Chuan.

 

 

Land Transport Review

 

     Mr Lim Biow Chuan (Marine Parade): Sir, I am a regular user of the CTE.  Last year, on the average, I paid $9.50 a day in ERP charges, just travelling up and down the CTE.  This amounts to about $190 per month, just on ERP charges.  Like many users of the expressways, I grumbled about having to pay ERP charges and yet see no improvement in traffic flow. 

 

    In January, when I heard about the Land Transport Review, I groaned in anticipation that ERP charges would go up again.  I was also frustrated by the increasing number of ERP gantries.  But, Sir, having thought over this problem, I have come to conclude, perhaps reluctantly, that LTA is correct. There is simply too much vehicle traffic on Singapore roads.  Perhaps when we allow

Column: 2333

3% new COEs every year, when we relax the car financing rules that allow too many Singaporeans to buy cars, whether they can afford it or not, it is not realistic to expect Singaporeans having bought expensive cars that they would not want to use them and simply leave them at home.

 

 

The depreciation costs of not using a car will be too high to bear.

 

12.15 pm

 

     With more and more Singaporeans owning cars and wanting to use them, I support the Government's move to regulate road congestion by pricing road usage appropriately, and let me say that again, "appropriately".  This will allow motorists to decide whether they want to pay for smoother ride or whether they wish to save the ERP charges by using alternative roads or by using public transport.  For example, when I use the CTE in the evening, by paying the ERP charges for both gantries, at least I save journey time by travelling faster.  In the past, even if I were in an emergency and needed to reach my destination faster, I simply had no choice but to join the traffic jam.  If you need an example, just try using the CTE to rush home on a Friday or Saturday night, anytime from 10.00 pm onwards.  Another example: I would try to reach the ERP gantry at Braddell before 8.30 in the morning so that I can avoid paying the $4 ERP charge.  The $2 saving has affected my driving pattern.  I am sure that many motorists would behave likewise.  Price affects consumer or motorist's behaviour. 

 

    But, as I said last year, raising ERP charges as a means to manage traffic has its limitations.  I was thus pleased to hear of the Government's three-pronged approach to managing traffic congestion, that is, besides raising ERP charges, it would continue to improve the road capacity and also the public transport

Column: 2334

network. So if you want me to leave my car behind and take public transport, then the public transport better be up to mark.

 

     There are a few matters which I would like MOT to clarify.

 

     (1) Would LTA review the ERP charges downwards for the CTE, PIE and ECP when the Kallang-Paya Lebar Expressway (KPE) is fully open for use in September 2008?  After all, KPE would have expanded the road capacity for the north and north-eastern part of Singapore.

 

     (2) When LTA takes over the centralised planning of bus network next year, would LTA consider not just having additional premium buses to cater to the rich, but also basic bus services for the less well-off who only want a convenient bus to connect them to the city area, Orchard Road or the town centres?  Would LTA consider bringing back basic bus services similar to that of "Scheme B" buses, which previously operated during the morning and evening peak hours?  They provide a cheap and convenient bus service which caters to many lower income commuters.

 

     Next, I call on LTA to ensure that public transport operators provide connectivity, comfort and convenience for the residents and not merely be concerned about operating routes that are profitable.  An example would be service CSS 608 which was cancelled last year because both SMRT and SBS Transit did not wish to operate a service which was not profitable.  As a result, many of the commuters in Marine Parade and Tanjong Rhu were left struggling to cope with a more expensive and longer ride using another service.  LTA should also review all the bus routes to make sure that buses do not take too circuitous routes just to pick up more passengers.  To make public transport a choice mode, we must make public buses more convenient and trains less jam-packed during the peak hours.

 

    

Column: 2335

Just as we have full-day bus lanes for passengers so that they will not waste time, I think we can also ask the trains to run at more regular intervals during non-peak hours because train passengers also do not wish to waste time. 

 

    I also wish to ask MOT whether they will consider accelerating the opening of the Circle Line, not just for five stations, for the entire line. Lastly, can I ask MOT to update this House whether they intend to have a dedicated ratio station providing traffic information during peak hours, so that drivers can plan their route better so as not to contribute to traffic congestion?

 

 

          The Chairman:  Mr Seng Han Thong, you have two cuts.  You can take them together.  Six minutes total.

 

Public Transport Review

 

     Mr Seng Han Thong (Yio Chu Kang): Sir, the National Transport Workers' Union (NTWU) supports the key recommendations of the land transport review and is optimistic about the future for its members.  Together with the management of SBS Transit and SMRT, we held three dialogue sessions with 200-over union leaders to hear the members' concerns.  As a result, NTWU has recently submitted a response paper on the review to MOT with seven  recommendations for MOT's consideration.

 

     We are confident that all these measures would lead to a more efficient, affordable and reliable public land transport system after the revamp.  It will also provide more new job openings, better opportunities and better compensation for our workers.

 

    It is expected that the public transport ridership will go up from the present 63% to 70%.  The public transport operators have been asked to put in more buses on the road to enhance their services.  Here,

Column: 2336

I would like to clarify on an age-old belief that buses add to traffic congestion rather than help to ease traffic congestion.  Let me illustrate.  A typical single deck bus can carry up to 87 commuters and a double deck bus about 140 commuters.  So, on average, each bus can carry 100 commuters.  Assuming each car carries four passengers and if we can succeed in encouraging all to switch to take bus, then 25 cars will be off the road.  Thus, the effect of putting more buses on the road would in effect carry more commuters who otherwise would have travelled on cars.

 

    However, to the operators, putting more buses on the road means more capital cost to incur.  Not only do they have to incur huge cost to buy and sustain new buses, they would also have to pay more ERP charges at double the rates at gantries as buses are classified as very heavy goods vehicles.  With the new gantries and higher fee charges, it is estimated that the two operators have to pay the increased ERP charges from the present $3.5 million to about $5.5 million.  As we will be introducing distance-based fare structure, we are also not too certain yet on whether the fare would be lower or higher in the future and how this will impact on the operators’ cost.  Hence, the overall effect of all these may result in the operators having to incur higher operating costs which would actually translate to less sharing in terms of bonus, welfare and benefits for our workers in these companies.

 

     Sir, I must declare that I am not the shareholder of these two companies.  I am speaking on behalf of my members.  We view buses as an essential component to provide the solution for a seamless public transport and, in actual fact, thus help reduce traffic congestion.  More importantly, a seamless transport system would not happen without the hard work of our workers.  To the Government, the collection of ERP charges for buses is in effect

Column: 2337

cost neutral.  Therefore, we would like to urge the Minister to consider reducing or even waiving the ERP charges for buses.  The savings from the ERP charges for the operators could then be ploughed back to benefit and improve the welfare of the workers and encourage more Singaporeans to join the industry.

 

Public Transport Workers

 

     Sir, every morning, thousands of commuters will wait at the bus stops island-wide.  When the bus arrives, they will board, tap their fare card, take a seat or, if crowded, stand throughout the journey till they get down at their destination.  Not many will be too bothered with greeting the driver or remembering the face of the driver.  However, whenever any unforeseen or unfortunate incidents happen, the bus driver would be the first one to be blamed.  Fortunately, the majority of our bus crews goes about performing their job professionally and takes criticisms and sometimes scoldings from commuters in their stride.

 

     Sir, while we are supportive of more competition in the bus routes, we want to ensure that it is not done at the expense of commuters or our workers' interest and welfare.  In particular, the tendering process for bus routes package should not become an avenue for "cheap sourcing" by existing or new operators resulting in the employment of contract and lowly paid workers, including more foreign cheap labour.  We urge the MOT to consider formulating a basic framework and standards on the employment terms and conditions during the bidding and tendering process to refrain company from engaging in "cheap sourcing".  This is an important and critical process in ensuring our workers' interest and their morale are kept in balance while we strive for better

Column: 2338

and efficient service standards for the transport system.

 

    Similarly, I want to highlight the daily needs of our members working at the bus terminals.  I certainly welcome the proposal to build more integrated hubs with built-in bus terminals.  These modern structures are well ventilated and with modern and clean facilities.  This augers well not only for commuters but also make it comfortable for our members working inside the terminal.  I would urge LTA to take into consideration in their planning stage, the needs of the bus drivers and staff working for the operators to ensure that basic amenities like toilets, canteen and crew rest rooms are properly catered within the bus terminal so that they need not travel too far given the tight rest period – normally, it is 15-20 minutes – they have in between their duties and rest times.

 

Road Usage and Public Transport

 

     Ms Jessica Tan Soon Neo: Sir, the recent completion of the Ministry of Transport's Land Transport Review had the Ministry announced the plans to put the commuters' needs in the centre of public transport.  By making bus travel a more attractive travel mode, by expanding the rail system and work management to keep our roads smooth flowing, these are necessary measures and provide clear and comprehensive measures to address the growing demand of the land transport system in Singapore, and are definitely welcomed.

 

     In my dialogues and walkabouts and interaction with residents, many support the plans and measures but have expressed concerns at the pace of the cost measures being implemented, while the improvements to the infrastructure and the capacity of the public transport system are being phased in.  In 2007, there were seven new ERP gantries introduced and now there are plans in

Mr Cedric Foo raised the issue of tender design. He suggested that one possibility is that the revenue risk be taken by the Government and the cost risk by the public transport operators, as is done in London. In London, this has translated into an ever-growing state subsidy for the bus system.  If the Government takes on the revenue risk, then the PTO has no incentive to increase patronage.

He said that you get this phenomenon in London of running "ghost buses". Few people were taking the bus, but the operators still ran those buses because the State was paying them for it. But I think the point to make is that there is really no perfect model here and we will need to study all these and see what is best, given our circumstances, for Singapore.

There are, however, two operating principles that we will adhere to.


    (i) We will retain the current financial discipline that PTOs must be self-sustaining.


     Our consultants highlighted that this is one of the key positive features of our system that most other cities (except Hong Kong and Tokyo) have not managed to do. In Singapore, the operating costs of the public transport system are covered by the operating revenues. We must keep it this way so that our PTOs continue to operate efficiently. If we lose this discipline, it is the taxpayer who would ultimately pay for it. This is why it is important to emphasise the point that LTA taking the central planner role does not mean that the profitability of routes is no longer a consideration.  Once we shift away from this financial discipline, we will soon be running many routes that are under-utilised and paid for by the public purse. LTA will see how best to package routes, profitable and less profitable routes, to ensure the package as a whole is commercially viable.


     (ii) The second principle is to ensure a performance-based element that is tied to the operating rights.


     This way, operators are incentivised, even during the term of service, to provide a high level of service. For example, London introduced Quality Incentive Contracts (QIC) in 2001 as part of their bus contracts which ran for three to seven years. Under these contracts, bus operators have to fulfil key service requirements such as reliability and frequency of bus services and even bus drivers' attitudes and driving standards. This, together with other measures, has led to higher operating efficiencies, higher service standards and an increase in bus ridership.

For the rail industry, competitive tendering is not new.  When we awarded the Circle Line (CCL), it was through a tender. What is new is that we will shorten the duration of the future operating licences from the current 30-40 years to 10-15 years to enhance contestability.

The National Transport Workers' Union (NTWU) sent a submission to me on the Land Transport Review recently. One of the key points they made is that more competition may well enhance their employment prospects. Indeed, the signs actually point towards a larger public transport pie over time as more people take public transport and service levels go up. Daily public transport trips are expected to double the next 12 years, from the current 5 million to 10 million by 2020. At the end of the day, whether we have two public transport operators or more, we will still need bus captains and other service staff to keep our system up and running, and good staff will always be in demand.

Beyond that, it is best not to introduce labour market distortions by prescribing special employment terms to which public transport operators must adhere. Public transport workers should be subject to the same competitive dynamics as workers in other industries. The best way to help them is not protection but rather to find ways to

The more important issue here is that the Government has taken steps to help bus companies. Buses are exempt from COEs. The statutory lifespan of buses has been extended through the years, from 12 years to 17 years. Bus companies are charged a nominal rent for the bus interchanges, and they are allowed to keep the commercial rental revenue which comes to $2 million to $3 million a year. Through the years, we have also reduced road tax; the savings are about $13 million every year.

Mr Wee brought up the point that the costs of public transport services should be made transparent and asked how we can incentivise PTOs to rein in their costs. Dr Lam asked whether the costs would be passed on directly to commuters.
 

    On the issue of transparency, this is already the case today. Public transport operators are listed companies, so this information on costs is readily available. More importantly, the fare formula we have today is not a cost-plus formula. Instead, it is a price cap that is tied to macroeconomic factors like inflation and wage increases. This means that if the public transport operators do not manage their costs well and they shoot up, they will not get a larger fare increase because of that. The fare cap is fixed each year, based on these macroeconomic factors and the public transport operators are not left to raise fares as they wish. In

addition, any productivity gains that the PTOs enjoy will ultimately be shared with commuters through the clawback mechanism, that is the sharing of productivity gains.


     Hence, I would like to assure Dr Lam that the additional costs of the public transport improvements will not be directly passed on to commuters. In fact, the public transport operators may be spurred on by the competition, to improve their productivity. The Public Transport Council (PTC) also monitors the affordability of public transport closely to ensure that fares remain affordable for the majority of households over time.

 

     It is this price cap formula that protects commuters and guards against public transport operators raising their fares as they wish. It incentivises the PTOs to rein in their costs. It has been three years since the fare adjustment formula was put in place. The weights in the formula are up for review to ensure their continued relevance. This is something that the Public Transport Council is already doing and I understand the PTC expects to complete the review by the middle of the year.


     Every now and then, you hear this argument that, because public transport services are public services, they should therefore be run by non-profit making entities with fares kept cheap by subsidies. You hear echoes of this in the Chamber every now and then. But ultimately we need to understand that there is no free lunch. If you look at past examples where transport services are run by state entities, the lack of a profit motive results in higher, not lower, costs.  With no incentive to reduce cost or maximise revenue, it is not surprising that the efficiency of such entities is very low. Let us take an example. In Jakarta, with the same fare tariffs, one set of public transport operators are run by the state; another set by private operators. And the

Column: 2364

one run by the state is always asking for subsidy and losing money. But the one run by the private operators keep their costs low and they make a return. The reason is that they have the financial discipline.


     Operating subsidies are also not an answer.  In other cities where public transport fares are kept lower than what it costs to operate, the result is over-consumption by all, including the rich. The costs are ultimately passed on to taxpayers. So our system is better. Our operators have the incentive to be efficient; there is a shared understanding that the Government, the public transport operators as well as the commuters all chip in to pay for what they get. Any help needed for the lower income will be targeted to them.

     Sir, the war against terror is increasingly complex.  Aided by sophisticated technology, terrorist groups are now able to extend their ideological reach and inflict harm beyond the immediate boundaries of countries or regions.  In recognition of the globalised threat of terrorism, the international community has developed a series of 13 international counter-terrorism conventions within the framework of the United Nations to combat this threat.  To date, Singapore has acceded to eight of them, the most recent being the International Convention on the Suppression of Terrorist Bombings in December 2007.
